case.title: CJ-FF-PRD-2026-02 — Maldoc Macro → mshta → Encoded PowerShell
case.description:
### Narrative
A recovered Office document contains an obfuscated macro. When executed, it spawns mshta and launches encoded PowerShell to download and run stage-2.

### What you must prove
1) Macro intent (deobfuscate strings safely, offline)  
2) IOCs extracted (URLs/domains, file paths, registry keys, cmdline tokens)  
3) Detections that would have caught this earlier (Sigma-first)  
4) How you would validate and scope the incident in Elastic

### ATT&CK mapping
- TA0002 / T1204.002 — User Execution: Malicious File  
- TA0005 / T1218.005 — Mshta  
- TA0002 / T1059.001 — PowerShell  
- TA0005 / T1197 — BITS Jobs (staging)

tasks.title: Extract and deobfuscate macro strings safely (offline)
tasks.description: Do not execute. Focus on string decoding and intent reconstruction.

tasks.title: Extract IOCs and create hunting pivots
tasks.description: Generate KQL pivots for URL/domain/hash/cmdline tokens.

tasks.title: Correlate endpoint execution with Zeek DNS/HTTP
tasks.description: Tie macro output to network traffic windows.

tasks.title: Sigma-first: create 1 detection and 2 tuning variants
Scope and eradication plan
tasks.description: Identify other hosts/users likely impacted and evidence required to close.

notes.title: Macro Analysis Guidance
notes.content: Treat the macro as untrusted. Use string extraction and decode functions; never enable Office execution in the lab VM beyond controlled artifacts.

notes.title: IOC Hygiene
notes.content: Normalize domains and URLs. Store in case observables; tag as IOC only after validation against evidence.
